Experience Senior Packaging Engineer Intel Corporation June 2014  – Present (1 year 3 months) Chandler, AZ Research and develop new integrated CPU sockets/connectors for upcoming client/server products 
o	Identify, research and develop new socket/connector/high speed I/O technology 
o	Select and enable supplier to deliver new and robust technology 
o	Interface with internal stakeholders by integrating electrical and mechanical core competency, materials, Q&R and surface mount team 
o	Define critical dimensions/tolerances, stack up, alignment and mechanical loading requirement to optimize electrical performance 
o	Design test vehicle and tooling to support prototype fabrication, validation and high volume manufacturing 
 Senior Test Engineer Intel Corporation October 2008  –  May 2014  (5 years 8 months) Chandler, AZ Develop and implement advanced test tooling technology for Intel’s server/desktop/mobile products. 
Lead design and qualification of first article sockets and handler kits for Class Test/Burn In module. 
o	Define tooling design rules and mechanical specifications 
o	Work with supplier closely for design concepts, prototype validation and first article deployment 
o	Review the final design with management/stakeholders and get approval 
o	Design tooling qualification collaterals 
o	Inspect first article critical to function dimensions 
o	Perform mechanical/thermal/electrical qualification and characterization of the test tools 
o	Investigate tooling quality problems, derive root causes and provide technical solutions 
o	Provide qualification report to stakeholders and document best known methods 
o	Drive cost reduction and tool conversion time reduction in high volume manufacturing 
o	Lead ISO9000 quality certificate on tooling development process

Summary I have obtained a B.A. degree in Physics, a M.S. in Optics, and a Ph.D. in Optics. The research focus for my dissertation is how visual effects impact a search and identification task. 
 
I specialize in semiconductor packaging R&D and laser/material interactions. Summary I have obtained a B.A. degree in Physics, a M.S. in Optics, and a Ph.D. in Optics. The research focus for my dissertation is how visual effects impact a search and identification task. 
 
I specialize in semiconductor packaging R&D and laser/material interactions. I have obtained a B.A. degree in Physics, a M.S. in Optics, and a Ph.D. in Optics. The research focus for my dissertation is how visual effects impact a search and identification task.

* Excellent verbal and written communication skills Experience Senior Packaging Engineer Intel Corporation May 2012  – Present (3 years 4 months) Chandler, Arizona * Lead engineer for thermal assessment of Intel products catering to mobile computing clients (tablets, ultra-books and laptops). Responsible for providing recommendations to package and chip architecture design teams to define thermal budget of different products. 
 
* Leading efforts in the group to develop transient thermal modeling capabilities. Improved accuracy and turnaround time using an innovative method for simplifying package thermal model generation. 
 
* Responsible for providing thermal requirements and collaborating with materials engineering teams to develop new materials with enhanced thermal properties for future packaging technologies. 
 
* Conducted CFD and multi-physics simulations of manufacturing processes and provided recommendations to process engineering teams for optimizing chip assembly processes. Graduate Student/Research Assistant Case Western Reserve University January 2007  –  April 2012  (5 years 4 months) Cleveland/Akron, Ohio Area * Actively collaborated with industrial partners through Research Commercialization Projects for the successful launch of novel graphite heat spreader. 
 
* Developed novel techniques for characterizing thermal transport in individual nanostructures and nanostructured bulk materials. Critical analysis of the results to find structure-property relationships. 
 
* Conducted Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) simulations for thermal management of building environments using COMSOL. 
 
* Extensive use of materials analysis/characterization techniques such as SEM-FIB, TEM, AFM, XEDS, XPS, AES, RBS, SIMS. 
 
* MEMS fabrication using Wafer Cleaning, LTO, LPCVD, PVD, DRIE, Wet Etching and Wire bonding. 
 
* Authored articles for publication in peer reviewed journals and presented in international conferences. 
 
* Trained and supervised several undergraduate students working on senior year projects. •	Experimental and numerical simulation background in multiphase flow and convection and radiation heat transfer Experience Senior Packaging Engineer Intel Corporation January 2014  – Present (1 year 8 months) Phoenix, Arizona Area •	Led Intel cross-functional teams and international vendors to design and manufacture High Speed interconnect components of 14nm server products and enabled successful product functional tests ahead of schedule.  
•	Drove the vendors to improve product quality and reliability, assembly yield and product mechanical and electrical performances while meeting multiple product development milestones. 
•	Established and correlated Low Level Contact Resistance and Critical to Function parameter measurement metrologies at Intel and vendors. Senior Process Engineer Intel Corporation January 2011  –  January 2014  (3 years 1 month) Phoenix, Arizona Area •	Installed, qualified and maintained Intel First Level Interconnect (FLI) substrate Micro-bumping link and Chip Capacitor Attachment link to support substrate High Volume Manufacturing ramp up. 
•	Drove equipment suppliers to continuously improve tool quality, reliability and capacity to meet various volumes of multiple products manufacturing demand.  
•	Established Intel 14nm FLI micro-bumping and Land Side Capacitor Attachment processes by driving equipment suppliers to continuously improve tool quality, reliability and capacity and leading material suppliers to optimize direct materials to meet substrate yield and manufacturability targets. 
•	Enabled 10nm fine-pitch micro-bumping processes with high yield to support Intel’s future product roadmap.  
•	Led fundamental solder joint characterization such as voiding reduction, shear strength and Intermetallic Compound microstructure, and established process baselines of micro-bumping and capacitor attachment.  
•	Initiated and established Pack/Ship Module to enable the 24/7 operation across different Intel sites.
